content.description: Recommended as a toprope only, as there is no gear to keep your body out of the boulder jumble if you blow the cruxy slab moves under the roof.  But it has been led.  Start at the base of the arete on a pointed block.  Immediately start angling right onto the slab.  When you get to the roof, traverse left to the obvious jam crack that cleaves the bulge.
content.protection: Gear and/or trees for the anchor. Best to hang the rope a few feet to the right of the crack through the bulge, or else a fall off the slab will swing the climber onto something hard below.  If falls are likely, two ropes might not be a bad idea.
content.location: Go left into the canyon that is south (left) of the Golden Dreams face.  You'll see the profile of the route on the right.  A good view can be had from atop the Skink block (see the route photo)

content.description: A high-angle slab, face climb from hell.  This route wanders for 10-15 feet back and forth as you struggle to connect the crystals that form your only holds.  If you're short (i.e., not 5'9"), you might not even be able to start this climb; at 5'6", I couldn't even get off the ground.  Named Super Skink because, as the FA said, "It's totally sandbagged at 5.10; more like 5.10d or harder".
content.protection: There is absolutely no gear whatsoever.  Use the bolts for the Golden Dream to provide an anchor.
content.location: This route is on the face on the OTHER side of the Golden Dream route; go through the squeeze hole to the right.  The route starts on top of some stacked blocks/ledges, about 6-8 feet off the ground; go up for about 8 feet, then traverse right under the small roof for about 10-15 feet; go up about 5 feet, then traverse left for about 10-15 feet; go up to top.

content.description: Start a couple of feet left of Slot Machine (the huge off-width in the middle of the wall).  A bouldery start leads to to a stance; follow a finger crack to the top (crux).  It's 5.5 horizontals after the crux.

Grovel, grovel, and grovel some more in this full-body offwidth. Crux, for many, is just moving up - not everyone can climb offwidth.

 If you hate offwidths, this line can also be climbed without just hands in the main crack, finding small fee throughout the pebbly rocks on either side.
content.protection: Decent gear, especially off to the sides.  Gear-only anchor at the top.
content.location: Climb the big, obvious offwidth crack 10 feet left of Fickle Fingers and 20 feet left of Golden Dream.  Route goes to the right of the large chockstone at the top.  Easy walk-off.

content.description: It's hard to rate this climb since it would be easy to bail right to the arête for some easier climbing, or left to the chock stones. If you're moving through a thin 5.7 slab crux with a glorious left hand side pull, you're on the right line. After the crux, a couple easy slab moves and some huge ledges, it's all over.
content.protection: Almost no gear until after the crux, and still pretty sparse. TRable on a gear anchor extended over the edge.
content.location: Across from Sinister Urge is a thin slab. Start from a generous ledge with a sapling and climb up the right side of the slab. Avoid escaping to the arête.

content.description: Tucked back in the canyon left of the Golden Dreams wall is a broad arete with a vertical seam down low that leads to a very inviting jam crack through a bulge.  Scamper up onto the Skink block for a great look at this (see photo).  The initial seam is a fun enough aid line (C2, tiny gear of all kinds and a hook move), but this was freed recently at 5.13a.  Whichever way you do it, you're bound to enjoy the crack above (9+ or maybe 10a).
content.protection: The left-arching seam on the arete takes tiny gear and feels like PG.  The crack above takes normal stuff.
content.location: Enter the canyon left of Stinky Americans and you see the arete on the right about 30 ft ahead of you.  Start at the base of the arete, on a pointed boulder.

content.description: Fun, slightly overhanging fist jam in corner.
content.protection: G-GP pro, if you can unpump long enough to place it.  Gear-only anchor at top - do NOT use the Pitch Pines.
content.location: Same wall as Super Skink; to the right, there's a small alcove in the corner.  Climb obvious hand-fist crack at left of alcove.  Route starts in alcove.

content.description:
A fully-sustained fingercrack in a dihedral, that starts off just barely slab and ends up just barely overhanging. Look for small but reliable footholds scattered around the right face.

 Widely regarded as one of the best 5.9s you'll ever climb as well as one of the finest climbs at Peterskill or indeed all of the Gunks. Also, the climb on the cover of the Peterskill guide.
content.protection: G-rated - it's a sustained fingercrack.  There is a double-bolted anchor at the top.
content.location: Climb the fingercrack in the obvious left-facing dihedral on the right end of the Golden Wall alcove.  Easy to walk off.

content.description: Face/finger-crack climb followed by double roof.  Two cruxes - mid-height, and very long reach through roofs.
content.protection:
PG pro, small stuff. The roof (one of the cruxes of the climb) is a bit tricky to protect well.

 Two bolts at the top to set up a top rope.
content.location: Follow discontinuous fingercrack 10 feet left of Golden Dream, through roofs.

content.description: Start six feet to the right of Stinky Americans, follow face to top.

climbs.name: Chris' Cringe or Hatti's Horror
climbs.fa: Chris Moratz, Hatti Langsford and party

content.description: See route photo for Super Skink: start just left of where Super Skink starts. A couple of hard moves get you off the pedestal and up to the overlap. Move left from there to the arête. Beautiful climbing up the arête to the top.
content.protection: Toprope from the Golden Dream bolts, with directional.  It would be R/X to lead.
content.location: Around the corner (right) of Golden Dream -- start about 15 feet right of the arête.

content.description:
The middle third of this climb packs in all the difficulty and spans a variety of styles. Some very balance-y moves lower down, need to use underclings, compression with the roof, and also make a few big moves.

 The top section is a relative stroll.
content.protection: protection is small, and hard to place. Use the Golden Dream bolts to set up anchor.
content.location: Climb the arete 5 feet right of Golden Dream.

content.description: Home to one of the most popular routes in PK, the Golden Wall area is tricky to reach, but worth every effort.  Four of the several routes have double-bolted anchors.  The amphitheater gathers the sun's heat on cold days, and with so many routes in close proximity is the closest thing to a "gym-like" atmosphere with a group.  Routes from 5.6 to 5.12.
